recap_documents.description: ORDER denying 201 Motion for Leave to File. As should be evident from the Order to Show Cause, the issue is not whether Artificial Intelligence was used but whether Plaintiffs' motions at CM/ECF 174, 175, 176 and 177 breach Rules 1.1. and 3.3 of the Model Rules of Professional Conduct. Signed by Judge Raul M. Arias-Marxuach on 3/28/2025. (mrr) (Entered: 03/28/2025)

ORDER granting 178 Motion for Leave, 179 Motion for Leave, and 180 Motion for Leave. Defendants claim that Plaintiffs have used generative artificial intelligence and cited non-existent or erroneous authorities in recent submissions to the Court. The Court has conducted an independent review and find that Plaintiffs' motions at CM/ECF 174, 175, 176, and 177 contain multiple citations that are incorrect, do not contain the quotes or content cited to, and reference cases that cannot be located and thus presumably do not exist. While the use of generative artificial intelligence is not forbidden, attorneys have a duty of competence to their clients and a duty of candor to the tribunal. The duty of competence requires "the legal knowledge, skill, thoroughness and preparation reasonably necessary for the representation." See Model Rule 1.1 of the Model Rules of Professional Conduct. The duty of candor toward the tribunal prohibits making false statements of law to the Court. See Model Rule 3.3 of the Model Rules of Professional Conduct. Plaintiffs shall have until March 25, 2025 to file a memorandum showing cause as to why sanctions should not be levied against them. Signed by Judge Raul M. Arias-Marxuach on 3/18/2025. (mrr) (Entered: 03/18/2025)

AMENDED ORDER TO SHOW CAUSE: Defendants claim that Plaintiffs have used generative artificial intelligence and cited non-existent or erroneous authorities in recent submissions to the Court. The Court has conducted an independent review and finds that Plaintiffs' motions at CM/ECF 174, 175, 176, and 177 contain multiple citations that are incorrect, do not contain the quotes or content cited to, and reference cases that cannot be located and thus presumably do not exist. While the use of generative artificial intelligence is not forbidden, attorneys have a duty of competence to their clients and a duty of candor to the tribunal. The duty of competence requires "the legal knowledge, skill, thoroughness and preparation reasonably necessary for the representation." See Model Rule 1.1 of the Model Rules of Professional Conduct. The duty of candor toward the tribunal prohibits making false statements of law to the Court. See Model Rule 3.3 of the Model Rules of Professional Conduct. Plaintiffs shall have until March 25, 2025 to file a memorandum showing cause as to why sanctions should not be levied against them for violations of the aforementioned rules of professional conduct and of Fed. R. Civ. P. 11 (b)(2) (stating that signing a pleading, written motion, or other paper certifies, to the best of the attorney's knowledge, information, and belief, formed after a reasonable inquiry, "that the legal contentions within are warranted by existing law or by a nonfrivolous argument for extending, modifying, or reversing existing law or for establishing new law"). Signed by Judge Raul M. Arias-Marxuach on 3/19/2025.(mrr) (Entered: 03/19/2025)
